block.p: Officials Linked to Hussein To Be Charged Next Week The first charges will be filed next week against former members of Saddam Hussein's government, starting the long-awaited effort to bring him and his aides to justice, Ayad Allawi, Iraq's interim prime minister, announced. In central Baghdad, a suicide bomber killed three Iraqi national guard officers and wounded 12 at an entrance to the fortified Green Zone.

Responding to the threat of roadside bombings and ambushes of American ground convoys in Iraq, the Air Force is sharply expanding its airlift of equipment and supplies to bases inside the country to reduce the amount of military cargo hauled over land routes, Air Force officials said.

An audit board set up by the Security Council to monitor oil sales in Iraq during the 15 months that the United States-led occupation authority ran the country reported that there had been widespread mismanagement, including financial irregularities, a failure to curb smuggling and overdependence on no-bid contracts.

Abbas Condemns Uprising Mahmoud Abbas, left,the favorite to win the Palestinian election for president next month, said in an interview that the armed uprising against Israel was a mistake and must end. It was his most explicit condemnation of Palestinian violence recently and appeared to signal his intention to chart a different strategy following the death of Yasir Arafat.

Global Warming as Rights Issue The Eskimos, or Inuit, of the Arctic plan to seek a ruling that could create the foundation for an eventual lawsuit charging that the United States, by contributing substantially to global warming, is threatening their existence.

Kerik's Past Undetected In Interviews for Cabinet Despite hours of confrontational interviews of Bernard B. Kerik by the White House counsel, Alberto R. Gonzales, the White House failed to get a full picture of the legal and ethical problems in Mr. Kerik's past that derailed his nomination for homeland security secretary, a government official said.

Questions on Ohio Voting The ranking Democratic member of the House Judiciary Committeeplans to ask the Federal Bureau of Investigation and a county prosecutor in Ohio to explore ''inappropriate and likely illegal election tampering,'' in at least one and perhaps several Ohio counties.
3 Awarded Medal of Freedom President Bush bestowed the nation's highest civilian honor, the Presidential Medal of Freedom, on three of the central architects and executors of the war in Iraq.

Romney Critical of Intelligence Gov. Mitt Romney of Massachusetts, the leader of a national working group on domestic security, said that to protect America against terrorists, state and local agencies, as well as private businesses, need to gather intelligence themselves and not rely only on intelligence gathered by the federal government.

8th Graders Making Progress Eighth-grade students in the United States performed better in both mathematics and science last year than four years earlier but still lagged behind their peers in a number of other industrial countries, according to a survey of student performance in 46 countries.

In Court, Sheik Assails Prosecution and Defense A Yemeni sheik fighting terrorism-financing charges told a federal judge in Brooklyn that prosecutors had offered him $1 million to become an informer, and said his American defense lawyer appeared to be siding with prosecutors.
Subway Worker Killed A subway worker was struck and killed by a train in Brooklyn as other members of his work crew looked on in horror.

$6 Million for Chauffeurs The New York City Board of Elections, which says it cannot afford to upgrade its antiquated voting system, recently signed contracts valued at $6 million to provide car services for employees who work late, according to city procurement records.

Pataki Hints at Plans Governor Pataki said he would not make a decision about his political future until after the next legislative session, but hinted that he would prefer to run for a fourth term rather for the United States Senate.

Settlements in AOL Cases Time Warner is expected to announce that it has reached a settlement withthe Justice Department in its investigation of certain advertising transactions between America Online and smaller Internet companies that allowed America Online to exaggerate its growth. The company may also announce that it has reached a tentative agreement with the enforcement division staff of the Securities and Exchange Commission.
Fed Raises Rates Again The Federal Reserve raised shortterm interest rates for the fifth time this year and suggested that more rate increases are in order in the months ahead.
Editorials: No bang for our cheap buck; Michael Leavitt moves on; a trial for General Pinochet; moving the Barnes.
Columns: Nicholas D. Kristof, William Safire.
